My favorite nutrient-dense salad to pack on the go! Quick to make, easy to clean up! 

You can use the recipe below or make up your own. The key is to buy a 4-5 oz container of spring mix, remove a handful from the top to make room for your other ingredients (save those extra greens for later). Then just dump a bunch of ingredients into the spring mix container, close the lid and shake. 

Ingredients:
-1 4-5 oz container spring mix
-Diced onions
-Sliced radishes
-1/2 avocado
-Cherry tomatoes
-2-3 hard boiled eggs
-Primal Kitchen ranch dressing 

Save this post for nutrient-rich inspo for when you’re on the road or super busy! 

#beingbrigid #nutrientdense #foodismedicine #functionalnutrition #functionalmedicine #healthylunchideas #antiinflammatory #bloodsugarbalance

Anti-inflammatory Cinnamon Lemon Ginger Tea 🍋🍋

The ingredients in this tea have a powerful ability to lower inflammation! 

Ingredients
8 cups filtered water
2 lemon wedge, quartered
1 bunch mint leaves
8 cinnamon sticks
1 fresh ginger root, peeled and sliced

Instructions
Fill pot with filtered water.
Add lemon wedges, mint leaves, cinnamon sticks and ginger.
Bring water to a boil.
Reduce stove to simmer and enjoy throughout the day or remove from stove and pour into a glass jar to drink throughout the week. Can store in refrigerator!

Save this for a cozy tea recipe this winter! 🌞🫖🌱🍋 

#inflammation #inflammationrelief #beingbrigid #functionalmedicine #functionalnutrition #metabolichealth

Hormonal imbalance was the most popular health topic from my poll yesterday! So here we are…

Essentially hormonal imbalance is often (not always but definitely often) a downstream consequence of other upstream imbalances. That’s why in my nutrition programs we rarely recommend hormone testing as the first place to start.

This is also one of the many reasons that I strategically focus on the buckets that have the most impact on other systems, namely: blood sugar imbalances, inflammation & gut health. 

The most common root causes of hormonal imbalance that we see are:
-Blood sugar imbalance
-Poor gut health
-Inflammation
-Nutrient deficiencies (like magnesium, fatty acids, certain B vitamins)
-Mitochondrial dysfunction 
-Undereating
-Poorly managed stress
-High toxic burden (too many environmental pollutants and chemicals compared to what your body is capable of excreting) 

Save this post as a reminder of the areas you can focus on for hormonal health. And remember that everyone has different root causes! The key is to work with a practitioner to identify what your root cause is. Applications for the January My Food is Health program are open if you’re interested in working with us to get to the root with nutrition. 

#beingbrigid #functionalmedicine #functionalnutrition #foodismedicine #hormonebalance #hormonehealth

If you’ve spent too many years of your life wasting energy on calorie restrictive deprivation diets, you can find freedom and better health in changing your food mindset. 

Full disclosure: I never fell into calorie-restricted deprivation diets. Because I started using food as medicine when I was 15 (thanks to my parents!), I’ve always focused on how food makes me feel. It was something that I figured out because I was so desperate to stop having so many seizures and to actually be awake for a full hour straight. That motivated me to always want to nourish my body. 

But if you are like many of our clients, restrictive deprivation diets may be hardwired into your brain. When you shift to thinking about how food makes you feel, decreasing symptoms, nourishing your body and infusing your cells with nutrients, it changes e.v.e.r.y.t.h.i.n.g. It’s not always easy to change this overnight but in time, it is possible!

If you are working on your relationship with food, join us for My Food is Health. A healthy food mindset and relationship are the foundation of long-term consistency with nutrition. Apply for our January program at the link in my bio! 

#beingbrigid #myfoodishealth #foodismedicine #feelinggood #functionalnutrition #functionalmedicine

Of all the content that I produce this past year, this is the most shared & viewed Reel of 2022! Likely because many of you have unfortunately had a similar experience. Going into 2023 with the confidence that nutrition is critical in disease pathophysiology and health creation and you can find credible experts to help you use food as medicine, even if your doctor isn’t yet aware of how nutrition can help. 

REPOST…
One of the most common things that I’ve heard from clients in my digital coaching business and patients when I worked in a hospital is: “my doctor said there’s no need to change my diet. They said there’s no research to show it will work for (insert disease).”

What many doctors don’t disclose is that medical school trains doctors to diagnose and treat disease with medication and surgeries. This is important! But nationally, doctors receive less than 18 hours of nutrition education in medical school. 

Had I listened to my neurologist who adamantly stated “nutrition has nothing to do with your condition”, I’d very likely still have several mini seizures per day and would not be nearly as functional as I am today. 

Chronic inflammation & blood sugar imbalances are the two primary drivers of chronic disease and autoimmune disease. And the largest contributor to inflammation & blood sugar imbalances is an inflammatory diet. 

Here’s the thing: drugs have a place. But if you want to support your health and functionality, adopting an anti-inflammatory diet is critical and backed by an abundance of research. No drug can mask the consequences of an inflammatory diet, sedentary lifestyle, poor sleep or chronic stress. And what I’ve seen in working with thousands and thousands of clients is that when you decrease inflammation, you can often decrease your dependence on pharmaceuticals. 

Tell me about your personal experience in the comments below! And please share this with a friend who would benefit from this message. 

#metabolichealth #inflammation #foodismedicine #functionalnutrition #functionalmedicine #bloodsugarbalance #antiinflammatorydiet #chronicpain #beingbrigid

A year and a half ago we got pregnant and then lost the baby at 9 weeks. I waited to miscarry naturally which never happened so I had a D&C at 13 weeks.

It felt like my world was turned upside down emotionally but even worse than the emotional pain was how bad I felt physically from the hormonal changes. When I woke up I had zero energy, I felt SO depressed and I gained 10 lbs without changing my diet/lifestyle. My doctor refused to test hormones, said this was normal & that once my period came back, we were fine to start trying again. 

I knew that if I wanted to get pregnant again and have a healthy pregnancy that I needed to focus on regaining my health. So that’s what I did for more than a year. I doubled down and treated my health like I was in training as an Olympic athlete. I actually didn’t workout intensely—did low impact exercises to keep stress low—but was even more focused on my health than ever. 

Even though I have been working on my health for the last 17 years since I was diagnosed with my neurological autoimmune disease, this took things up a level. I was desperate to feel like myself again and so motivated to support my hormones, blood sugar and mitochondria in order to make a healthy pregnancy possible and easier on my body.

If you have experienced pregnancy loss, infertility or the postpartum changes that can happen-I feel your pain. Deeply. If anything, I would say don’t give up on yourself. Focus on blood sugar optimization, nutrient deficiencies, stress reduction and inflammation since these directly impact hormonal health. 

If you are looking to make changes to support fertility or postpartum recovery, I would genuinely love to help you in our Jan My Food is Health. The items that I focused on are essentially the roadmap that we teach in My Food is Health. And I conducted the nutrient deficiency lab testing that we run on everyone in MFIH on myself. You don’t have to keep struggling on your own. 

This isn’t about weight loss although weight gain/loss can happen as a side effect of health challenges/improvements. It’s about literally coming back to life and preparing for new life! Link for MFIH is in my bio! 

I’m cheering you on.💓

Stop accepting that you are unhealthy, unhappy, and constantly stressed. This is no way to live and you deserve BETTER! 👏👏👏 

Stop jumping from generalized diet to diet and expecting different results. Diets don’t work and will only continue to set you up to fear food and feel like a failure. 

Here’s what I want you to embrace: you get a fresh start on the year! So start believing that you can change your state of health. You can change how you feel daily. You can stop the dieting cycle. You can stop feeling unhealthy, unhappy and constantly stressed if you are willing to put in the work. You are worth the work! 

That work starts with changing what you put on your plate and better understanding what works best for you because food fuels the 37 trillion cells in your body. 

My team and I would love to help guide you to better understand what you personally need in our 10 week signature My Food is Health program. Click the link in my bio for more information and to apply!

The optimal morning fasting glucose range is 70-90 mg/dL (some experts would even argue 70-85). 

I’ve been interpreting glucose labs and CGM data for 10 years and my team of dietitians @beingfunctionalnutrition do this for all of our clients bc it’s so important!!

There’s three ways to know this information: 
-Look at your fasting glucose from your most recent doctors appt 
-Wear a continuous glucose monitor 
-Use a glucometer 

There are lots of potential root causes for elevated morning blood glucose levels. They will vary for every person. 

Some people will have elevations bc they ate a high glycemic meal too close to bed whereas others may be elevated because they are doing too many fasted workouts, drinking coffee on an empty stomach and waking up with high perceived stress. 

Comment below if you are working on lowering your morning fasting glucose levels! 

#beingbrigid #beingfunctionalnutrition #bloodsugar #bloodsugarbalance #cgm #foodismedicine #functionalnutrition

This Creamy Chocolate Grain-free Banana Bread is a fan favorite in my house! 

I’ve also tested this bread on a Continuous Glucose Monitor several times and it has a low glycemic impact for me. Save this post for future reference. You can also find the recipe here: https://beingbrigid.com/recipes/creamy-chocolate-grain-free-banana-bread/

INGREDIENTS
3 ripe bananas, mashed
1/2 medium avocado, mashed
1/2 cup almond butter
4 eggs
1/4 cup coconut oil, melted
2 tbsp grass-fed butter, melted
2 tsp vanilla extract
1/2 cup coconut flour
1 tsp cinnamon
1 tsp baking soda
1/4 tsp himalayan salt
1 scoop grass-fed whey protein powder
1/2 cup dairy-free dark chocolate chips

INSTRUCTIONS
Preheat oven to 350 F.
In a large bowl combine mashed banana and avocado in addition to almond butter, eggs, melted coconut oil, melted butter, and vanilla extract.
Whisk all wet ingredients.
In a small bowl combine coconut flour, cinnamon, baking soda and whey protein powder.
Stir all dry ingredients together.
Slowly pour dry ingredients into large bowl and add chocolate chips.
Mix all ingredients well.
Pour into a greased loaf pan.
Bake for 45-50 minutes or until the bread is cooked in the very middle.

#beingbrigid #foodismedicine #lowglycemic #bananabread #functionalnutrition #functionalmedicine

What you feed your body impacts how much you can get out of this one life that we have to live. You deserve to have the energy to pursue your dreams, to support your loved ones, to play with your kids, to hike that mountain, to crush it at work, to live your life! 

Your energy is directly impacted by the food choices that you make overtime. Food is medicine for your 37 trillion cells which also means it is our most direct source of fuel. 

This is why the “everything in moderation” mindset can do a great energetic disservice. Even a 10% increase in ultra-processed foods increases risk of early death by 14%. Our food supply is filled with foods that are not food and are not even meant to be eaten in moderation. 

This does not mean being perfect. But consistently making optimal choices most of the time as a way of life.

The best kept secret to making more optimal nutrition choices during the week: set aside 60 minutes to prep simple, convenient and nutrient-dense staples. 

In my new Youtube Episode, I walk you through 3 Anti-Inflammatory Meal Prep Staples that I like to prep on a Sunday afternoon, in 60 minutes or less, to help keep me on track during the week.

Here’s the first recipe:

Canned Salmon Salad

Ingredients:
3 cans of wild salmon
3 Tbsp avocado oil mayonnaise (or olive oil mayonnaise)
6 celery stalks
6 pickles 
¼ red onion, diced

Instructions:
1-Dump 3 cans of wild salmon into a bowl.
2-Add 3 Tbsp of avocado oil-based mayonnaise and mix together.
3-Chop celery, pickles, and red onion. Add to the salmon mixture and combine. 
4-Serve or store in a sealed glass container in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.

If you feel like you are trying everything but struggling to see results, you may want to look closer at your approach.

Welcome to the world, our sweet & resilient baby McKinley. 

Last week McKinley entered our world and ripped our hearts wide open. The level of gratitude that Johnny and I feel for her life and health is impossible to put into words. 

We had done everything to try to increase the chances of having a vaginal birth to help support her microbiome and immune system. But God had other plans. After 30 hours of laboring, I got an infection which led to a 102 fever that wouldn’t break and increased her heart rate into the 180s. We rushed in for an emergency c section. And when she arrived, our obgyn shared that her umbilical cord was wrapped around her neck 3 times and she isn’t sure what the outcome would have been had we pushed for a vaginal birth. 

Every time I look at her I’m reminded of how precious life is. I’m in awe of what an absolute miracle she is. And so grateful that she fought for us as hard as we were fighting for her. 

Thank you to all of our friends, family and to each and every one of you for your prayers, well wishes, messages, calls, breastfeeding tips, clothes, flowers, and love. Thank you to modern medicine and the amazing nurses and doctors that cared for us. And thank you to my amazing husband for the incredible support, diaper changes, swaddles and love. This past week has been so emotional, beautiful, exhausting and miraculous. We love you, McKinley!

3 weeks of the sweetest baby snuggles, quality family time and figuring out how to parent! 

Highlights: Johnny trained McKinley to hold up her own bottle; Johnny’s teaching himself how to golf while wearing a baby; I’m learning how to breastfeed and pump (thank you @drinklmnt electrolytes); and teaching McKinley about her gut microbiome. 

I’m super focused on: 
💫Optimal nutrition & hydration for recovery and breastfeeding. The way that I see it: Ignoring my health is ignoring her health bc what I eat is in a sense what she eats. 
💫Foods for gut healing & wound healing: grass-fed beef sticks, frozen pineapple, bone broth, collagen/beef protein powder & smoothies, probiotic rich foods, pumpkin seeds, green juices.
💫Daily supplementation to try to make up for the nutrients that I used during pregnancy and am losing with breastfeeding. Especially @we_natal prenatal, fish oil, magnesium, & more. 
💫Pumping every 3 hours. I’m mostly pumping and we bottle feed her breast milk which seems to help her sleep better and has helped me mentally. We do 1-2 breastfeeds per day. 
💫Snuggling and bonding together and getting that oxytocin release! 
💫A few minutes of sunshine daily. 
💫Researching a million things like infant probiotics, integrative medicine pediatricians, etc. 

I’m excited to get back to posting content this upcoming week! Ive missed you the last few weeks but am so grateful for the time unplugged with my precious family and excited to share more of how we are supporting our health during this busy stage of life!

Public service announcement: Serving inflammatory, high glycemic meals to patients in the hospital should not be normalized in healthcare! 

When patients are critically ill, hospitalized for chronic disease complications, or recovering from surgery, this is when humans need the highest quality nutrition, not the lowest! 

When I was in the hospital after giving birth I ordered the standard hospital meal one time to see what it included. Your typical breakfast: 87g of carbs from REFINED buns/toast, orange juice (aka liquid sugar), crispy potatoes and fruit and only 25g of protein. 

This meal will cause a huge blood sugar spike for pretty much anyone which will be followed by an increase in inflammatory cytokines. Not to mention the jelly with corn syrup and smart balance with seed oils. 🫠🫠🫠

The “Nourish Room” on the L&D floor had free snacks for patients that included Gatorade with tons of added sugar and artificial sweeteners, cereal with refined grains, Jif peanut butter packets, and Ensure with artificial sweeteners & added sugar. 😭😭😭

It’s a real life example of Wendell Berrys famous quote: “People are fed by the food industry, which pays no attention to health, and are treated by the health industry, which pays no attention to food.”

I look forward to the day that the US spends more on quality food to support better healing and overall health in order to spend less on healthcare in the end and stops subsidizing grains, corn, and sugar that are used in highly processed foods which makes jelly with corn syrup significantly more affordable than other options for large corporations and hospitals.

Your microbiome is the epicenter of your health with more than 100 trillion microbes. 

Antibiotics wipe out both good and bad microbes–they do not just target the harmful bacteria. So the first thing is to avoid unnecessary use of antibiotics. A 2016 CDC report estimated that at least 30% of antibiotics prescribed in US are unnecessary.

But sometimes there’s no way around them. I experienced this when in the hospital giving birth. So here are 5 things that are very important for helping to support gut health post-antibiotics. 

1-Eat whole foods! The bacteria inside of you eat the foods that you eat. When you eat optimal foods, the population of beneficial bacteria grow. Avoid ultra processed foods which hijack the health of the gut microbiome and increase inflammation that can lead to more separations in the gut lining.

2-Prebiotic rich foods like apples, avocado, garlic, onions, jicama, lupini beans. Prebiotics are carbohydrates that humans can’t digest, but gut bacteria can. They selectively nourish the good bacteria who, in turn, produce beneficial compounds for you like short chain fatty acids.

3-Food sources like yogurt, dairy-free yogurt, kefir, sauerkraut, kimchi are helpful in addition to a probiotic supplement if you have been on an antibiotic. This will help to support the regrowth of beneficial microbes that are also targeted by antibiotics. 

4-Collagen, beef protein, & bone broth all contain high levels of an amino acid called l-glutamine–the most important nutrient for healing & repairing the intestinal lining. 

5-Supplements to support microbiome & gut lining: prebiotics, probiotics, zinc, vitamin D, omega 3s. Every person’s supplement needs will vary based on your unique needs. One supplement that is designed specifically for post-antibiotics is a probiotic called ABX Support by Klaire Labs.

These Low Glycemic Pumpkin Pancakes by @beingbrigid , are not only delicious but also support blood sugar balance, making them perfect for fertility health. 🎃🥞 

Swap out refined flours for almond flour and coconut flour, resulting in a lower glycemic impact.Plus, these pancakes are gluten-free, dairy-free, and grain-free! 🙌 

With their higher protein content, these pancakes will keep you satisfied for hours after enjoying them. 😋

For toppings, we recommend adding a drizzle of almond butter and a sprinkle of pumpkin pie spice.  If you prefer a touch of sweetness, go for almond butter, pumpkin pie spice, and a tablespoon of pure maple syrup. Remember, limit added sugar to one tablespoon per day for day-to-day indulgence. 🙅‍♀️🍯

Ready to whip up these IG-worthy pancakes? 👩‍🍳

Fertility-Friendly Pumpkin Pancakes
WeNatal x Being Brigid 
**Ingredients:**
- 1 cup almond flour
- 1/2 cup coconut flour
- 2 tsp baking powder
- Dash of Himalayan salt
- 6 eggs
- 1 1/2 cup unsweetened almond milk
- 1/2 cup canned pumpkin
- 6 drops stevia
- 1 tsp vanilla extract
- Avocado oil spray
- Optional toppings: pumpkin pie spice, almond butter, pure maple syrup

**Instructions:**
1️⃣ In a medium-sized bowl, combine almond flour, coconut flour, baking powder, and Himalayan salt.
2️⃣ In another bowl, mix the liquid ingredients: eggs, almond milk, canned pumpkin, stevia, and vanilla extract.
3️⃣ Slowly pour the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients and mix well.
4️⃣ Heat a large pan over medium heat and spray with avocado oil.
5️⃣ Pour 1/4 cup of batter onto the pan to make one pancake. Repeat to make three pancakes at a time, depending on your pan’s size.
6️⃣ Cook for about one minute, then flip and cook the other side for an additional minute.
7️⃣ Repeat until all the batter is used.
8️⃣ Serve the pancakes with your favorite IG-ready toppings like almond butter, pumpkin pie spice, and/or pure maple syrup. (remember: Go light on the maple syrup!) 

Don’t forget to share with your pancake loving friend 🤍

Adding apple cider vinegar to your diet has been shown in research to have several health benefits. 🍎🍏🍎🍏

Comment HEALTH and I’ll send you a link to my latest YouTube video where I breakdown everything you want to know about ACV!

3 Easy Ways:
🍏Add 1-2 Tbsp to sparkling water (hack: use a soda stream to carbonate the water) & drink with a straw to protect your enamel.

🍏Add 1-2 Tbsp to cinnamon tea! The flavor combination is amazing for someone who doesn’t like ACV with just sparkling water. Add 2 cinnamon sticks to a mug, hot water & ACV.

🍏Add ACV to a salad dressing. Mix it with extra virgin olive oil & 2 Tbsp of dijon mustard. 

Benefits:
🍏Lowers post-meal glucose levels if you drink it before eating a high glycemic meal. When you eat a meal with starches, the acid slows down the digestion & keeps blood sugar more stable. I started seeing this in clients 7 years ago when I started using CGMs. 
🍏One RCT also showed that those who used 1-2 Tbsp ACV diluted in water for 12 weeks lost 4 lbs more than the control. The acetic acid in ACV is thought to reduce appetite by keeping you fuller for longer. 
🍏Supports healthy cholesterol levels. This has also been shown in a few research studies. 
🍏ACV is a prebiotic which means it can help support a healthy gut. There isn’t research to show this but mechanistically, prebiotics support the microbiome. Add it to your diet before meals, unless it causes reflux or other symptoms, move it to after meals. 

Comment the word HEALTH and I’ll send you a link to my latest YouTube video on everything you want to know about ACV!

Blood Sugar Balanced Recipe👇

Save this post for the perfect blood sugar stabilizing breakfast! 

Ingredients:
1 tbsp avocado oil
½ yellow onion, diced
1 garlic clove, minced
1 cup bell peppers, chopped
1 heirloom tomato, diced
2 cups arugula
1 tbsp basil
10 large eggs
¼ cup nut milk, unsweetened
½ tsp red pepper flakes
1 tbsp garlic powder
1 avocado, large
dash of salt
dash of black pepper

Instructions
🍳Preheat oven to 350 F.
🍳In a large skillet add avocado oil and heat over medium heat.
🍳Add onion, garlic and bell peppers.
🍳Once the onion starts to caramelize, add tomatoes.
🍳After 2 minutes, add arugula and basil and cook all vegetables for another 3 minutes.
🍳Pour vegetable mixture into a 9x11 baking dish.
🍳Pat vegetables with a paper towel to remove excess water.
🍳In a medium size bowl, whisk eggs, nut milk, red pepper flakes, garlic powder, salt, and black pepper.
🍳Pour egg mixture over the vegetables in the baking dish.
🍳Place in the oven for 25-30 minutes. Cut into 4 servings. Serve each quiche with 1/4-1/2 of an avocado.

Probiotics can be helpful BUT there’s SO much more required to have a healthy gut long-term. 

The gut microbiome is like an ecosystem with >100 trillion microbes. These microbes help to regulate each other. 

If you put a few strains of bacteria in a pill, it’s not going to be enough to reinoculate your entire gut. 

Here’s what will give you the greatest benefit: 

1-A comprehensive food-as-medicine approach. This is the most effective way to change your gut microbiome to support your health long-term. 

2-Prebiotic rich foods like apples, avocado, garlic, onions, jicama, lupini beans. Prebiotics are carbohydrates that humans can’t digest, but gut bacteria can. They selectively nourish the good bacteria who, in turn, produce beneficial compounds for you like short chain fatty acids. You may also want to consider a prebiotic supplement. 

3-Don’t forget about your gut lining! This is just as important as your microbiome! Your intestinal lining is key for lowering inflammation, decreasing GI symptoms and supporting hormone balance. 

Collagen, beef protein, & bone broth are some of my favorites. And possibly an l-glutamine supplement. 

What questions do you have about gut health? Include them 👇!

How to screw up your hormones when you’re in reproductive years: skip breakfast, eat no carbs & fuel your day with coffee. 

Here’s a little more on the science:
🫐Super low carb diets can be a stressor on the body which increases cortisol which can actually increase your blood sugar levels! Sometimes with our clients we actually increase carbs in their diet and their fasting blood sugar, thyroid markers & weight improve. 

🫐Not eating breakfast means missing out on an opportunity to fuel your body first thing. It sets the tone for the day and is going to break your fast. While fasting can have huge benefits for some people (depending on season of life), that doesn’t mean you have to skip your breakfast.

I also want to emphasize: you can balance blood sugar without removing all carbs from your diet!

Where do I even start if I want to improve my health and support blood sugar, inflammation and gut health?!

After working with more than 8,000 clients, these are the top three places I recommend starting to get super consistent with in order to create a strong foundation. And they happen to be FREE!

1) Sleep! 
Get so serious about creating a consistent sleep routine and get at least 7 hours of sleep. This helps to balance your hunger hormones and blood sugar and decreases cravings the next day. If you aren’t sleeping, it will take way more “willpower” to stay consistent with your diet. 

2) Hydrate!
Dehydration can increase blood sugar levels and also impairs gut health. It also zaps your energy! Your body doesn’t know the difference between hunger and thirst. Set a goal of drinking half of your body weight in fluid ounces and track everyday whether you are meeting that goal. It’s best if you can get filtered water. 

3) Pay Attention! 
Pay attention to how you FEEL after eating certain foods, after sleeping well, after moving your body. And also pay attention to how you feel after you overeat sugar, alcohol or refined grains. Track it on my Food Symptom Journal. This is one of our key resources in my programs. 

DM me FSJ and I will send you my Food Symptom Journal for free!

This high protein meal prep staple is supportive of hormone health, blood sugar balance & lowering inflammation. 

Save this recipe for a super quick way to get the same benefits as fresh wild salmon. 

Ingredients:
3 cans of wild salmon
3 Tbsp avocado oil mayonnaise (or olive oil mayonnaise)
6 celery stalks
6 pickles 
¼ red onion, diced

Instructions:
1-Dump 3 cans of wild salmon into a bowl.

Switching out coffee for matcha is a simple way to support your central nervous system and your hormones! 

Coffee can work for plenty of people but if you are struggling with hormonal symptoms, you may want to decrease stimulants like caffeine and alcohol to decrease the cortisol response. 

Benefits of Matcha:
1️⃣High in EGCG, a powerful polyphenol that lowers inflammation (less inflammation=better hormone health)
2️⃣Contains chlorophyll, a phytochemical that lowers inflammation
3️⃣Has L-theanine which is calming and helps supports alertness & lower anxiety (aka energy without coffee jitters)
4️⃣Has about 60mg of caffeine (2x higher than regular green tea but less than coffee)

How I make an unsweetened matcha latte 🍵

🍵Heat water to 150 F & pour a few tablespoons into the mug
🍵Add 1-2 tsp organic, ceremonial grade matcha (depends on how thick you like it)
🍵Mix with a milk frother
🍵Fill the mug 3/4 of the way with hot water
🍵Fill the rest with unsweetened coconut or almond dairy-free creamer (I use @nutpods)
🍵Enjoy!

Matcha brand that I love: @piquelife. But there’s lots of other good brands that are more affordable. This is not sponsored!

If you feel like you don’t eat a lot but still can’t lose weight, this could be part of the reason.

Eating too many starches and added sugar is the most common driver of insulin resistance (which fuels weight gain, hormonal imbalance & inflammation). But that’s one of several potential factors!

Insulin resistance can also be caused by chronically elevated cortisol levels.

If you are constantly experiencing stress, always packing your calendar, regularly self-sabotaging, not sleeping enough, under eating and overexercising…you’re likely over activating your sympathetic nervous system regularly. 

Constantly running on cortisol can lead to converting your body’s stored form of sugar (glucagon) into circulating sugar in your blood stream. So blood sugar rises even without eating added sugar! 

Chronically high cortisol can also breakdown your muscle and the gut lining bc it’s a catabolic hormone (increasing GI symptoms and leaky gut). 

When your muscles are breaking down and you are pulling amino acids from them, you have less ability to store glucose which makes it much easier to gain body fat, experience inflammation and become insulin resistant. 

For a full breakdown on the science of supporting your hormone health and decreasing this cortisol response, DM me HORMONE and I’ll send you my free hormone guide!

Nutrient deficiencies aren’t just driven by insufficient intake of nutrients in the diet (which is more common today since our soil is depleted), but also because of poor gut health which lowers nutrient absorption. 

Common nutrient deficiencies include:
✨magnesium
✨omega 3 fats 
✨vitamins A & C
✨B vitamins

Start with nutrient deficiency testing to see your own personal needs and then work towards improving your nutrient status.

Here is the strategy that I’ve used to help thousands of people transform their health, relationship with food, confidence, and metabolism.... 

The people who get the most incredible results focus on one thing: CONSISTENCY over perfection! 

If you are constantly going through cycles of being “really good” and then “really bad” with your diet, you likely will not see longterm results. 

For as much as I BELIEVE in functional medicine lab testing and better understanding the root of health conditions, I promise you after 10 years as a functional medicine dietitian, the secret to blood sugar balance and less inflammation starts with getting REALLY consistent. 

Here is what I recommend focusing on: 
-Do an audit of your pantry and fridge to determine the foods that you already have on hand. 
-Choose no more than 2 blood sugar balancing recipes for breakfast, lunch and dinner so that you aren’t setting yourself up for failure. 
-Schedule time for grocery shopping every week or every other week. If you use meal delivery services, you still need to plug the time into your calendar to help you be consistent. 
-Prep your produce in advance (wash & chop your onions, peppers, celery, etc.) 
-Schedule the time that you need to prep a few of the recipes in advance to save you time throughout the week. 
-Follow the “Apocalypse diet” during other meals—that means throwing together the easiest possible foods that will give you the protein, fat & fiber that you need. 
-Don’t expect yourself to be perfect at every meal. Move on as quickly as possible when you eat a less optimal meal. 

If you are looking for a SYSTEM that works, stay tuned for my announcement next week. I cannot wait to support you and this community in the most robust way imaginable!

400 Calories Vs 400 Calories! 🫐🧁🫐🧁

If you’ve tried calorie counting diets in the past that end up not working long-term, this is a big reason! 

Two meals with the same number of calories can create very different metabolic effects and glucose responses that impact your satiety cues and other symptoms.

A Blueberry Muffin and our Blueberry Muffin Smoothie are both about 400 calories. 

The difference is in your glucose response! The blueberry muffin may taste great short-term but it’s all empty calories that provide little nourishment and will cause your blood sugar levels to rise. This leads you to feeling tired, drives cravings and increases brain fog. 

Compare that to a Blueberry Muffin Smoothie that also tastes delicious but has 30g of protein and 12g of fiber plus healthy fats to help you feel energized, satiated and mentally clear throughout the day. 

Just a reminder that calories are not created equal!! Paying attention to blood sugar balance & nutrient-density is essential. This should be nutrition 101.

The two huge areas to focus on: 

Your blood sugar balance AND gut health which are two key areas that influence everything happening in the body, from inflammation & immune health to hormonal imbalance to detoxification. 

Here is where I would recommend starting:
1-Blood sugar balancing meals that include protein, fat & fiber. 

2-Limit grazing as this can support blood sugar balance and also support your migrating motor complex (MMC) or your “housekeeper” that helps with digestion by clearing food particles. 

3-Increase diversity in your diet. Get a lot of rotation between different fruits, vegetables, nuts and seeds. More food variety helps increase microbiome diversity that supports better digestion. Meal planning can really help here! 

4-Limit added sugar in your diet. This can play a key role in not just supporting blood sugar but also feeds less pathogenic bacteria. 

5: Take 5 deep breaths before meals & eat in a low stress state. Not only do stressors increase cortisol & blood sugar, it also lowers digestive enzyme production. Focus on slowing down and being present with your meal!
